oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Lecture - Michael Lydon - 2006-03-10
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Lecture by Ray Charles biographer Michael Lydon from the Ford Theatre at the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum on March 10, 2006. In support of the exhibit I Can’t Stop Loving You: Ray Charles and Country Music.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Michael Lydon;
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: Recording begins in progress. Includes excerpts of selected audio recordings and questions from the audience. Opening comments by Michael Gray. Introduction of Michael Lydon -- Thoughts on writing biographies -- Ray Charles traveling around the country -- Listening to country music by staying up late listening to the Grand Ole Opry as a child -- Musical threads that Ray followed -- Searching for background on the Florida Playboys -- The birth of Ray's musical direction and wanting to perform country music -- Record company resistance to allowing Ray to record country music -- The background behind the title of the album Modern Sounds of Country and Western Music -- Reads story from the book by Sid Feller regarding the song I Can't Stop Loving You - Plays recording of I Can't Stop Loving You with comments over -- Ray continuing to record country songs the rest of his career -- Demonstration of the chord of nature by playing guitar string --

Musical theory -- Ray's success with recordings lead to growing his empire -- Reads story from the book by Ruth Robinson regarding Ring Of Fire -- Combining different forms of music to make Ray Charles music -- Ray's success providing income to Acuff Rose Publishing -- Partial list of country songs recorded by Ray -- Ray's time in Nashville -- Working with CBS Records and producer Billy Sherrill -- Comments on the movie Ray -- Ray's motivation for making music -- Ray controlling his own catalog -- Ray's concept albums -- Closing comments.
